## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 388, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 415, 390, 433]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 446, 782, 463]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 463, 322, 478]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 478, 504, 494]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 494, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 509, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 910, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 599, 598, 615]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 614, 608, 630]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 643, 608, 659]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 659, 757, 675]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 675, 440, 691]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 517, 92]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 104, 156, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 104, 280, 123]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(X = 2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 280, 440, 299]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{P}(X = n) = \mathrm{P}(X = n + 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 312, 153, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 312, 393, 330]]<|/det|>
Write down an equation in \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 312, 920, 330]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 488, 153, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 488, 470, 507]]<|/det|>
Hence or otherwise find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
It is claimed that, on average, a particular train journey takes less than 1.9 hours. The times, \(t\) hours, taken for this journey on a random sample of 50 days were recorded. The results are summarised below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 123, 656, 144]]<|/det|>
\[n = 50\qquad \Sigma t = 92.5\qquad \Sigma t^2 = 175.25\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 160, 153, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 160, 690, 178]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 160, 920, 178]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 504, 91]]<|/det|>
Test the claim at the \(5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
The heights of a certain variety of plant are normally distributed with mean \(110\mathrm{cm}\) and variance \(1050\mathrm{cm}^2\). Two plants of this variety are chosen at random. Find the probability that the height of one of these plants is at least 1.5 times the height of the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
The manufacturer of a certain type of biscuit claims that \(10\%\) of packets include a free offer printed on the packet. Jyothi suspects that the true proportion is less than \(10\%\) . He plans to test the claim by looking at 40 randomly selected packets and, if the number which include the offer is less than 2, he will reject the manufacturer's claim.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 152, 156, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 151, 455, 170]]<|/det|>
State suitable hypotheses for the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 361, 154, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 361, 460, 380]]<|/det|>
Find the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 640, 92]]<|/det|>
\(X\) is a random variable with probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[388, 98, 606, 151]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}\frac{a}{x^2} & 1\leqslant x\leqslant b,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 157, 348, 174]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 188, 156, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 186, 329, 208]]<|/det|>
Show that \(b = \frac{a}{a - 1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 189, 920, 207]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 600, 186, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 600, 625, 618]]<|/det|>
Given that the median of \(X\) is \(\frac{3}{2}\), find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 602, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
All the seats on a certain daily flight are always sold. The number of passengers who have bought seats but fail to arrive for this flight on a particular day is modelled by the distribution B(320, 0.005).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 120, 156, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 604, 139]]<|/det|>
Explain what the number 320 represents in this context.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 330, 153, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 330, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
The total number of passengers who have bought seats but fail to arrive for this flight on 2 randomly chosen days is denoted by \(X\). Use a suitable approximating distribution to find \(\mathrm{P}(2< X< 6)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 361, 920, 380]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<form>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
After some changes, the airline wishes to test whether the mean number of passengers per day who fail to arrive for this flight has decreased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 153, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
During 5 randomly chosen days, a total of 2 passengers failed to arrive. Carry out the test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
